text:
Your default path is being ignored because your HTTP Request has a path set. 
Defaults do not over-ride set values - they only over-ride blank values.  If you
want the request to use the path from the defaults, leave it's path blank.
creator: mstover1@apache.org
simon.beaumont@biowisdom.com
text:
On that basis I'd need a HTTP Defaults for every webservice I need to test. 
Since by definition there is no inheritance - by appending paths to defaults - 
so I fail to see the point. Unless of course there is an inheritance hierarchy 
of the HTTP Request Defaults. 

The idea is not having to modify every request when I switch to testing a 
different server or application on the same server.

I expect the actual requests to have the invariant bit (the webservice name) 
and the rest to be inherited from the HTTP Request Defaults. Cleary this is not 
how it works. Sorry for the misunderstanding.

what you want is user-defined variables.

You set your paths in your requests to
${partThatChanges}/stuff/that/stays/the/same.

Then, in TestPlan, you define the variable "partThatChanges", and when you move
your test, just change that variable.
